text: Without thinking highly either of men or of matrimony , marriage had always been her object : it was the only honourable provision for well - educated young women of small fortune , and , however uncertain of giving happiness , must be their pleasantest preservative from want .

text: As he was to begin his journey too early on the morrow to see any of the family , the ceremony of leave - taking was performed when the ladies moved for the night ; and Mrs. Bennet , with great politeness and cordiality , said how happy they should be to see him at Longbourn again , whenever his other engagements might allow him to visit them .

text: “ My dear madam , ” he replied , “ this invitation is particularly gratifying , because it is what I have been hoping to receive ; and you may be very certain that I shall avail myself of it as soon as possible . ”
text_tokenized: “ My dear madam , ” he replied , “ this invitation is particularly gratifying , because it is what I have been hoping to receive ; and you may be very certain that I shall avail myself of it as soon as possible . ”

text: They were all astonished ; and Mr. Bennet , who could by no means wish for so speedy a return , immediately said,-- “ But is there not danger of Lady Catherine ’s disapprobation here , my good sir ?
text_tokenized: They were all astonished ; and Mr. Bennet , who could by no means wish for so speedy a return , immediately said,-- “ But is there not danger of Lady Catherine ’s disapprobation here , my good sir ?

text: You had better neglect your relations than run the risk of offending your patroness . ”
text_tokenized: You had better neglect your relations than run the risk of offending your patroness . ”

text: “ My dear sir , ” replied Mr. Collins , “ I am particularly obliged to you for this friendly caution , and you may depend upon my not taking so material a step without her Ladyship ’s concurrence .
text_tokenized: “ My dear sir , ” replied Mr. Collins , “ I am particularly obliged to you for this friendly caution , and you may depend upon my not taking so material a step without her Ladyship ’s concurrence .

text: “ You can not be too much on your guard .

text: Risk anything rather than her displeasure ; and if you find it likely to be raised by your coming to us again , which I should think exceedingly probable , stay quietly at home , and be satisfied that _ we _ shall take no offence . ”
text_tokenized: Risk anything rather than her displeasure ; and if you find it likely to be raised by your coming to us again , which I should think exceedingly probable , stay quietly at home , and be satisfied that _ we _ shall take no offence . ”

text: “ Believe me , my dear sir , my gratitude is warmly excited by such affectionate attention ; and , depend upon it , you will speedily receive from me a letter of thanks for this as well as for every other mark of your regard during my stay in Hertfordshire .

text: The steady countenance which Miss Lucas had commanded in telling her story gave way to a momentary confusion here on receiving so direct a reproach ; though , as it was no more than she expected , she soon regained her composure , and calmly replied,-- “ Why should you be surprised , my dear Eliza ?
text_tokenized: The steady countenance which Miss Lucas had commanded in telling her story gave way to a momentary confusion here on receiving so direct a reproach ; though , as it was no more than she expected , she soon regained her composure , and calmly replied,-- “ Why should you be surprised , my dear Eliza ?

text: “ I see what you are feeling , ” replied Charlotte ; “ you must be surprised , very much surprised , so lately as Mr. Collins was wishing to marry you . But when you have had time to think it all over , I hope you will be satisfied with what I have done .

text: XXIII .

text: Elizabeth was sitting with her mother and sisters , reflecting on what she had heard , and doubting whether she was authorized to mention it , when Sir William Lucas himself appeared , sent by his daughter to announce her engagement to the family .
text_tokenized: Elizabeth was sitting with her mother and sisters , reflecting on what she had heard , and doubting whether she was authorized to mention it , when Sir William Lucas himself appeared , sent by his daughter to announce her engagement to the family .

text: With many compliments to them , and much self - gratulation on the prospect of a connection between the houses , he unfolded the matter,--to an audience not merely wondering , but incredulous ; for Mrs. Bennet , with more perseverance than politeness , protested he must be entirely mistaken ; and Lydia , always unguarded and often uncivil , boisterously exclaimed,-- “ Good Lord !
text_tokenized: With many compliments to them , and much self - gratulation on the prospect of a connection between the houses , he unfolded the matter,--to an audience not merely wondering , but incredulous ; for Mrs. Bennet , with more perseverance than politeness , protested he must be entirely mistaken ; and Lydia , always unguarded and often uncivil , boisterously exclaimed,-- “ Good Lord !

text: Nothing less than the complaisance of a courtier could have borne without anger such treatment : but Sir William ’s good - breeding carried him through it all ; and though he begged leave to be positive as to the truth of his information , he listened to all their impertinence with the most forbearing courtesy .
text_tokenized: Nothing less than the complaisance of a courtier could have borne without anger such treatment : but Sir William ’s good - breeding carried him through it all ; and though he begged leave to be positive as to the truth of his information , he listened to all their impertinence with the most forbearing courtesy .

text: Elizabeth , feeling it incumbent on her to relieve him from so unpleasant a situation , now put herself forward to confirm his account , by mentioning her prior knowledge of it from Charlotte herself ; and endeavoured to put a stop to the exclamations of her mother and sisters , by the earnestness of her congratulations to Sir William , in which she was readily joined by Jane , and by making a variety of remarks on the happiness that might be expected from the match , the excellent character of Mr. Collins , and the convenient distance of Hunsford from London .
text_tokenized: Elizabeth , feeling it incumbent on her to relieve him from so unpleasant a situation , now put herself forward to confirm his account , by mentioning her prior knowledge of it from Charlotte herself ; and endeavoured to put a stop to the exclamations of her mother and sisters , by the earnestness of her congratulations to Sir William , in which she was readily joined by Jane , and by making a variety of remarks on the happiness that might be expected from the match , the excellent character of Mr. Collins , and the convenient distance of Hunsford from London .

text: Mrs. Bennet was , in fact , too much overpowered to say a great deal while Sir William remained ; but no sooner had he left them than her feelings found a rapid vent .

text: In the first place , she persisted in disbelieving the whole of the matter ; secondly , she was very sure that Mr. Collins had been taken in ; thirdly , she trusted that they would never be happy together ; and , fourthly , that the match might be broken off .
text_tokenized: In the first place , she persisted in disbelieving the whole of the matter ; secondly , she was very sure that Mr. Collins had been taken in ; thirdly , she trusted that they would never be happy together ; and , fourthly , that the match might be broken off .

text: Two inferences , however , were plainly deduced from the whole : one , that Elizabeth was the real cause of all the mischief ; and the other , that she herself had been barbarously used by them all ; and on these two points she principally dwelt during the rest of the day .

text: A week elapsed before she could see Elizabeth without scolding her : a month passed away before she could speak to Sir William or Lady Lucas without being rude ; and many months were gone before she could at all forgive their daughter .
text_tokenized: A week elapsed before she could see Elizabeth without scolding her : a month passed away before she could speak to Sir William or Lady Lucas without being rude ; and many months were gone before she could at all forgive their daughter .

text: Mr. Bennet ’s emotions were much more tranquil on the occasion , and such as he did experience he pronounced to be of a most agreeable sort ; for it gratified him , he said , to discover that Charlotte Lucas , whom he had been used to think tolerably sensible , was as foolish as his wife , and more foolish than his daughter !
text_tokenized: Mr. Bennet ’s emotions were much more tranquil on the occasion , and such as he did experience he pronounced to be of a most agreeable sort ; for it gratified him , he said , to discover that Charlotte Lucas , whom he had been used to think tolerably sensible , was as foolish as his wife , and more foolish than his daughter !

text: Lady Lucas could not be insensible of triumph on being able to retort on Mrs. Bennet the comfort of having a daughter well married ; and she called at Longbourn rather oftener than usual to say how happy she was , though Mrs. Bennet ’s sour looks and ill - natured remarks might have been enough to drive happiness away .

text: After discharging his conscience on that head , he proceeded to inform them , with many rapturous expressions , of his happiness in having obtained the affection of their amiable neighbour , Miss Lucas , and then explained that it was merely with the view of enjoying her society that he had been so ready to close with their kind wish of seeing him again at Longbourn , whither he hoped to be able to return on Monday fortnight ; for Lady Catherine , he added , so heartily approved his marriage , that she wished it to take place as soon as possible , which he trusted would be an unanswerable argument with his amiable Charlotte to name an early day for making him the happiest of men . Mr. Collins ’s return into Hertfordshire was no longer a matter of pleasure to Mrs. Bennet .

text: Unwilling as she was to admit an idea so destructive to Jane ’s happiness , and so dishonourable to the stability of her lover , she could not prevent its frequently recurring .
text_tokenized: Unwilling as she was to admit an idea so destructive to Jane ’s happiness , and so dishonourable to the stability of her lover , she could not prevent its frequently recurring .

text: The united efforts of his two unfeeling sisters , and of his overpowering friend , assisted by the attractions of Miss Darcy and the amusements of London , might be too much , she feared , for the strength of his attachment .
text_tokenized: The united efforts of his two unfeeling sisters , and of his overpowering friend , assisted by the attractions of Miss Darcy and the amusements of London , might be too much , she feared , for the strength of his attachment .

text: As for Jane , _ her _ anxiety under this suspense was , of course , more painful than Elizabeth ’s : but whatever she felt she was desirous of concealing ; and between herself and Elizabeth , therefore , the subject was never alluded to .
text_tokenized: As for Jane , _ her _ anxiety under this suspense was , of course , more painful than Elizabeth ’s : but whatever she felt she was desirous of concealing ; and between herself and Elizabeth , therefore , the subject was never alluded to .

text: But as no such delicacy restrained her mother , an hour seldom passed in which she did not talk of Bingley , express her impatience for his arrival , or even require Jane to confess that if he did not come back she should think herself very ill - used .
text_tokenized: But as no such delicacy restrained her mother , an hour seldom passed in which she did not talk of Bingley , express her impatience for his arrival , or even require Jane to confess that if he did not come back she should think herself very ill - used .

text: It needed all Jane ’s steady mildness to bear these attacks with tolerable tranquillity .
text_tokenized: It needed all Jane ’s steady mildness to bear these attacks with tolerable tranquillity .

text: Mr. Collins returned most punctually on the Monday fortnight , but his reception at Longbourn was not quite so gracious as it had been on his first introduction .
text_tokenized: Mr. Collins returned most punctually on the Monday fortnight , but his reception at Longbourn was not quite so gracious as it had been on his first introduction .

text: He was too happy , however , to need much attention ; and , luckily for the others , the business of love - making relieved them from a great deal of his company .
text_tokenized: He was too happy , however , to need much attention ; and , luckily for the others , the business of love - making relieved them from a great deal of his company .

text: The chief of every day was spent by him at Lucas Lodge , and he sometimes returned to Longbourn only in time to make an apology for his absence before the family went to bed .
text_tokenized: The chief of every day was spent by him at Lucas Lodge , and he sometimes returned to Longbourn only in time to make an apology for his absence before the family went to bed .

text: [ Illustration : “ _ Whenever she spoke in a low voice _ ” ] Mrs. Bennet was really in a most pitiable state .
text_tokenized: [ Illustration : “ _ Whenever she spoke in a low voice _ ” ] Mrs. Bennet was really in a most pitiable state .

text: The very mention of anything concerning the match threw her into an agony of ill - humour , and wherever she went she was sure of hearing it talked of .
text_tokenized: The very mention of anything concerning the match threw her into an agony of ill - humour , and wherever she went she was sure of hearing it talked of .

text: The sight of Miss Lucas
text_tokenized: The sight of Miss Lucas

text: was odious to her .
text_tokenized: was odious to her .

text: As her successor in that house , she regarded her with jealous abhorrence .
text_tokenized: As her successor in that house , she regarded her with jealous abhorrence .

text: Whenever Charlotte came to see them
text_tokenized: Whenever Charlotte came to see them

text: , she concluded her to be anticipating the hour of possession ; and whenever she spoke in a low voice to Mr. Collins , was convinced that they were talking of the Longbourn estate , and resolving to turn herself and her daughters out of the house as soon as Mr. Bennet was dead .
text_tokenized: , she concluded her to be anticipating the hour of possession ; and whenever she spoke in a low voice to Mr. Collins , was convinced that they were talking of the Longbourn estate , and resolving to turn herself and her daughters out of the house as soon as Mr. Bennet was dead .

text: She complained bitterly of all this to her husband .
text_tokenized: She complained bitterly of all this to her husband .

text: “ Indeed , Mr. Bennet , ” said she , “ it is very hard to think that Charlotte Lucas should ever be mistress of this house , that _ I _ should be forced to make way for _ her _ , and live to see her take my place in it ! ” “ My dear , do not give way to such gloomy thoughts .
text_tokenized: “ Indeed , Mr. Bennet , ” said she , “ it is very hard to think that Charlotte Lucas should ever be mistress of this house , that _ I _ should be forced to make way for _ her _ , and live to see her take my place in it ! ” “ My dear , do not give way to such gloomy thoughts .

text: Let us hope for better things .
text_tokenized: Let us hope for better things .

text: Let us flatter ourselves that _ I _ may be the survivor . ”
text_tokenized: Let us flatter ourselves that _ I _ may be the survivor . ”

text: This was not very consoling to Mrs. Bennet ; and , therefore , instead of making any answer , she went on as before .
text_tokenized: This was not very consoling to Mrs. Bennet ; and , therefore , instead of making any answer , she went on as before .

text: “ I can not bear to think that they should have all this estate .
text_tokenized: “ I can not bear to think that they should have all this estate .

text: If it was not for the entail , I should not mind it . ”
text_tokenized: If it was not for the entail , I should not mind it . ”

text: “ What should not you mind ? ”
text_tokenized: “ What should not you mind ? ”

text: “ I should not mind anything at all . ”
text_tokenized: “ I should not mind anything at all . ”

text: “ Let us be thankful that you are preserved from a state of such insensibility . ” “ I never can be thankful , Mr. Bennet , for anything about the entail .
text_tokenized: “ Let us be thankful that you are preserved from a state of such insensibility . ” “ I never can be thankful , Mr. Bennet , for anything about the entail .

text: How anyone could have the conscience to entail away an estate from one ’s own daughters I can not understand ; and all for the sake of Mr. Collins , too !
text_tokenized: How anyone could have the conscience to entail away an estate from one ’s own daughters I can not understand ; and all for the sake of Mr. Collins , too !

text: Why should _ he _ have it more than anybody else ? ” “ I leave it to yourself to determine , ” said Mr. Bennet .
text_tokenized: Why should _ he _ have it more than anybody else ? ” “ I leave it to yourself to determine , ” said Mr. Bennet .
